bibdata.title: 1409 use holding_location label for the availability.json label
Empty deletion request getting a 404 from solr

comments.body:
As @hackartisan predicted, after this fix was deployed to the server we get a little bit more information on the error, the new Honeybadger alert is https://app.honeybadger.io/projects/54497/faults/79881407 and it includes the following information:

```
RSolr::Error::Http: RSolr::Error::Http - 404 Not Found
Error:     Not Found

URI: http://lib-solr8-prod.princeton.edu:8983/solr/catalog-alma-production-reindex/update?wt=json
Request Headers: {"Content-Type"=>"application/json"}
Request Data: "{\"delete\":[]}"
```

Notice that the delete dataset is empty (and malformed?). This should not result in a 404, though. But, this looks like progress :D
moving the new info to #1411 and closing this!

bibdata.title: Update the label in the availability.json in the item level
Update the label in the availability.json to pull information from the bibdata holding location label

comments.body: omg alma has too many different location formats! where are they even getting this "desc" string! Is it the value plus the external name? would stripping anything up through a colon work as desired?

The `location desc` string that we added as label in the availability.json is the alma location name. `“name”: “hy: East Asian Library”,`. It is a different value and has nothing to do with the external name. for example:
{“code”: “hy”,
“name”: “hy: East Asian Library”,
“external_name”: “”,
“type”: {“value”: “OPEN”,
“desc”: “Open”
},
“remote_storage”: “”,
“map”: “”,
“suppress_from_publishing”: “false”,
“fulfillment_unit”: {“value”: “General”,
“desc”: “General”
},
“accession_placement”: {“value”: “none”,
“desc”: “None”
},
“call_number_type”: {“value”: “”,
“desc”: null
},
Thanks for sorting through this. Pulling the value from the location table seems reasonable to me.

@mzelesky @kevinreiss should I update the label on the availability item level as well? Currently it takes the location desc and if it is a temp_location it takes the temp_location desc. If yes I will open another issue. https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1412
closed by #1410
follow up issue for the display https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/issues/2499

figgy.title: As a curator of archival material, I would like to hide some images from an object without deleting them, in order to show a more readable version of the content, while still preserving the full context for future research.

comments.body:
Background: The Derrida Seminars collection includes materials that were printed on reused paper, with unrelated correspondence on the backs of the documents. This creates a very disjointed reading experience.

The immediate request is to delete the images that are not related to the primary content to make a more readable version of the documents, though even that request comes with an acknowledgement that researchers in the future may be interested in the unrelated pages (e.g., to establish dates, or for their own sake). To avoid creating multiple overlapping versions of the same objects with many duplicate files, having a way to hide/suppress individual pages seems like the most straightforward way to me.

This is the use case for "non-paged" in IIIF I believe - if you set the viewer to paged display and then page through it'll "skip" the non-paged items, or offer them as fold-outs you can view in a different way that doesn't disrupt your viewing experience. The issue to support that in UV is quite old, with a comment from us in 2015. I'll ping the UV folks again and see if there's an implementation plan. Issue in question: https://github.com/UniversalViewer/universalviewer/issues/101
That's helpful — I thought that was what non-paged was for, but setting pages as non-paged in Figgy doesn't do anything because that lack of UV support.
@tpendragon If there's no movement from UV, how hard would it be to omit images marked as non-paged from the manifest?
Probably not too hard? Like a day or so unless some weird edge case appears.
@kelea99 found a PR to add support for non-facing to Mirador: https://github.com/ProjectMirador/mirador/pull/3029

figgy.title: Archival Media Collections should parse barcodes from EAD
Archival Media Bag Ingest is Broken

comments.body:
Today we found out:

The worker systems are running out of available file handles. The reason this is happening is because doing `Valkyrie::StorageAdapter.find_by(id: "")` initializes a file handle to the given file on disk. There's no way to close that handle, and Sidekiq is threaded so the process never goes away. So every file that's ever opened stays opened. Garbage collection seems to never clear up that reference, probably because of something in Valkyrie.

```ruby
f = File.open("/opt/repository/files/c8/dc/7c/c8dc7cba826940c1af8807052fb12da6/4f16c4243.tif")
# Open in lsof = 3
f = nil
GC.start
# Open in lsof = 0

f = Valkyrie::StorageAdapter.find_by(id: "disk:///opt/repository/files/c8/dc/7c/c8dc7cba826940c1af8807052fb12da6/4f16c4243.tif")
# Open in lsof = 3
f = nil
GC.start
# Open in lsof = 3
```

This seems to be because the IO is part of an instance variable, so GC doesn't grab it?

```ruby
class NewFile
   attr_reader :io
   def initialize(io)
     @io = io
   end
end

f = NewFile.new(File.open("/opt/repository/files/c8/dc/7c/c8dc7cba826940c1af8807052fb12da6/4f16c4243.tif"))
# lsof count = 3
f = nil
GC.start
# lsof count = 3
```

Apparently Valkyrie can register a finalizer to close the IO stream if it's garbage collected.

Edit: I can't get this to reliably work in a testable way in Ruby 2.x

So I think Valkyrie needs to:

* Provide access to #close 
* Not open a file descriptor until you're trying to read the content of a file.

orangelight.title: Retry call to bib data availability endpoint in the show page

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/40477050/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/40477050)

Coverage increased (+0.001%) to 96.73% when pulling **e4ec59fe84f7e0cd83e8f400727ae0f417128b4d on alma** into **8269f64cca0540c4535065c3e8ac7bd122d2d4d5 on main**.

Eliot found that this "had to do with bidata-staging not having any holding locations + caching of the empty result. Deleting everything in the Rails cache and setting `bibdata_base` to production bibdata did the trick.
https://bibdata-staging.princeton.edu/locations/holding_locations"
This error has nothing to do with the locations. @eliotjordan issue was that bibdata-staging was missing location flags and the button would not display for a specific record.
This error exists everywhere and in production as well.

Yes, something has happened with this feature in both production and alma-qa, I poked around and couldn't identify the root of the issue. There is js code in the requests gem that looks for datatables https://github.com/pulibrary/requests/blob/main/app/assets/javascripts/requests/requests.js#L184, that I think isn't finding the library. This form should be paginated and allow for search by enumeration when dataTables is working.

@kevinreiss should this be an issue in [requests](https://github.com/pulibrary/requests)?

The description says it's not breaking anything but according to your comment it is breaking functionality.

According to @kevinreiss it is breaking the requests form when there are big records. But I think we should troubleshoot in OL before we move it to the requests gem. Orangelight is also having the datatables gem but it seems that it is not loading properly.
Okay I updated title and description to make it look more like a real bug
Okay I updated title and description to make it look more like a real bug

orangelight.title: Handle location display for locations that don't have a holding_location label
Retry call to bib data availability endpoint in the SEARCH page
Implementing thumbnail rendering support for cases where Figgy GraphQL responses do not contain the bib. IDs

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/40492053/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/40492053)

Coverage remained the same at 96.73% when pulling **b05ab77e42a83694b07c2db6aa1e394c4d8bbe4f on issues-2411-jrgriffiniii-figgy-thumbs** into **e4ec59fe84f7e0cd83e8f400727ae0f417128b4d on alma**.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/40493924/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/40493924)

Coverage increased (+0.009%) to 96.738% when pulling **21f8c76a55ee1f0c78214ac6800df60d55b07e8a on 2439-read-only** into **8269f64cca0540c4535065c3e8ac7bd122d2d4d5 on main**.

Possibly related to this change: I'd like to see a [cache-control](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Cache-Control) header that sets a shorter life for this page. Right now my browser caches it and I have to do a hard-refresh to get the real content instead of the maintenance page.  (Currently it has last-modified and etag headers which are probably based on the html file, but that aren't really relevant for an error/maintenance page.)

Most often this problem happens when I try to access something that requires vpn before I'm actually _on_ vpn: try to access the site, get the maintenance page, login to vpn, reload the page — still maintenance page; hard refresh — see the actual content.

requests.title: Don't Display Copy Number label when copy number is 0
Status lozenge on the UI should show either Available or Unavailable not the real status

comments.body:
Based on current user feedback relayed from Alma Blacklight Open Houses there is a demand for staff to see the detailed statuses somehwere and the request form is the only place it can feasibly be provided due to Alma's API limitations for records that are not in the standard "Item In Place" location, the recommendations was to print out:

"Not Available - {status_label}"

Ex: "Not Available - Lost"

This is a combination two attributes in the availability response:

"{status} - {status_label}"
